2002.029.002 a
Wherever you go â€” your Travel Agent or Pan American repre-
sentative can help in many ways. He can assist you with travel
documents, reservations, and plan your itinerary for more pleasure
at less expense. Take advantage of his experience and be sure of
a trouble-free trip. In the Pacific area, Pan American maintains
offices in these cities:

PAN AMERICAN
WORLD'S MOST EXPERIENCED AIRLINE
Printed in U.S.A.
ViaN. 4WsP
PAD DR-1057-75

Information for
NON-RESIDENTS
strictly personal
Wearing apparel, articles of personal adornment,
toilet articles, etc., which you owned abroad and
are for your own use are exempt from duty and
internal revenue taxes, broadly speaking.
Other
personal effects also exempt are hunting and fish-
ing equipment, cameras for non-professional use,
wheelchairs, pet and hunting dogs, bicycles, baby
carriages, etc. You should be able to prove that
you owned them prior to your departure
that they are necessary, appropriate and intended
for your own use or wear ... and that they are
not for other persons or for sale. An article that
you bring in for sale or as a gift for another per-
son must be declared in writing.
if you're a SMOKER ..â€¢
... you'll be glad to know you can bring in one
of the following without having to pay duty or
internal revenue tax:
50 cigars â€¢
â€¢ or 300 cigarettes
â€¢ . . 01
3 pounds of smoking tobacco ... or 25 cigars
and 150 cigarettes ... or 25 cigars, 50 cig-
arettes and 1 pound of smoking tobacco.
BUT â€” they must be for your own use!
Adults may also bring in one quart of alcoholic
beverages â€” for their own use, and only if per-
mitted by law in the State to which they are
destined.
just passing through
Nonresidents in transit through the United States
to another country may take with them, free from
duty and internal revenue tax, personal items and
effects and dutiable articles not exceeding $200
in value. Consult Customs Inspectors for articles
exceeding this value you wish to ship through
U.S. without paying duty.
6
information for
ALL TRAVELERS
Gifts Valued Under $10
Because of a new regulation any gifts valued
under $10 can be shipped back to the U.S. Duty-
Free and they won't be counted against your
Duty-Free allowance if the total value of each
parcel does not exceed $10 and does not include
alcoholic beverages, perfume containing alcohol,
or tobacco. (IF total value does exceed $10, duty
and tax must be paid on full value.) This is a big
help to travelers in 3 ways. 1. Now you can pick
up bargains for friends, ship them home and
still make the personal purchases you originally
planned to bring in under the duty-free allow-
ance. 2. You're able to save valuable space, elim-
inate excess luggage. 3. You're able to simplify
customs formalities
... in each subsequent
country
... and when you re-enter the United
States.
Send as many gifts as you wish but not
more than one parcel a day to the same person.
Mark package "Gift" or use label as suggested
below. Air Parcel Post will carry such gift parcels
to the USA swiftly, safely. If you reside abroad,
you may send gifts in the same way â€” especially
useful during holidays.
Note: You don't have to deduct the value of
these gifts from your exemption.
Label Articles You Ship
Each package you ship will clear the U.S. Cus-
toms more quickly if you label it "Attention U.S.
Customs â€” Tourist Purchase Enclosed." Be sure
to indicate if you intend to declare the package
on your arrival in the U.S. or if it comes under
the regulations governing
"Gifts valued under
$10." For your convenience, a few of these labels
are provided with this booklet. If you need more,
just ask for them at any Pan American office.
can you declare ORALLY?
Under certain conditions you need only tell the
Customs inspector orally what articles you have
to declare. Your purser aboard the Clipper will
help you to determine if you qualify. In all cases
you'll have to make a written declaration if duty
or internal revenue tax is to be assessed or if
articles are shipped to you.
7
